citation-title.titletext: Reassessing Murder, She Wrote: The Afterlives of a Popular Culture Phenomenon

affiliation.ce:source-text: Eva Burke completed her PhD, funded by the Irish Research Council, at the school of English at Trinity College Dublin under the supervision of Dr. Clare Clarke. Her research looks at domestic noir fiction, specifically the work of Gillian Flynn. Eva has published work in the Journal of International Women’s Studies, Feminist Spaces and Trinity Postgraduate Review and the 2018 edited collection From the Domestic to the Dominant: The New Face of Crime Fiction, published by Palgrave Macmillan. She also co-edited a special ‘domestic noir’ issue of Clues: A Journal of Detection.

Jennifer Schnabel is associate professor and English subject librarian at The Ohio State University. She contributes scholarly book reviews to Clues: A Journal of Detection and Crime Fiction Studies, and her own research explores women and crime fiction. She recently co-chaired the Mystery and Detective Fiction Area of the Popular Culture Association and is the Research Support Officer for the International Crime Fiction Association.

abstract.publishercopyright: © 2025 selection and editorial matter, Eva Burke and Jennifer Schnabel; individual chapters, the contributors
abstract.ce:para: This book provides a critical overview of the cultural impact of the Murder, She Wrote TV series and its paratextual elements, including board and video games, podcasts, fan conventions, collectible figures, and ghostwritten novels. It also explores the series’ position within the crime genre, particularly its engagement with earlier iterations of the ‘lady detective’. Bringing together a broad range of experts, the book includes contributions from both academics and crime fiction novelists to offer a wide-ranging view of this popular series and its afterlives. Suitable for scholars and students working on popular culture, crime fiction, TV studies or fan studies, this collection provides an interdisciplinary analysis of one of the most successful and enduring female-fronted detective series in history.

abstract.publishercopyright: © 2025 selection and editorial matter, Eva Burke and Jennifer Schnabel; individual chapters, the contributors
abstract.ce:para: When Routledge announced a call for monograph proposals for their Advances in Popular Culture Studies series, a long-gestating dream was born: we thought the world desperately needed a collection of essays on the television show Murder, She Wrote. To us, and to fans around the world, amateur detective Jessica Fletcher is an icon, a canonical detective in the evolution of crime fiction as a genre, and a groundbreaking character that drove a long-running American television series and solidified its legacy. Since its original run on American TV, the show has been syndicated across the world, and continues to air internationally. The complete series is available on DVD, and the show is currently available to stream on several platforms, at least one for free, with episodes continuously on television networks in multiple countries.

citation-title.titletext: The Fairest of Them All: Jessica Fletcher’s Reign of the Queen of Mystery in Murder, She Wrote

affiliation.ce:source-text: Jennifer Schnabel is associate professor and English subject librarian at The Ohio State University. She contributes scholarly book reviews to Clues: A Journal of Detection and Crime Fiction Studies, and her own research explores women and crime fiction. She recently co-chaired the Mystery and Detective Fiction Area of the Popular Culture Association and is the Research Support Officer for the International Crime Fiction Association.

abstract.publishercopyright: © 2025 selection and editorial matter, Eva Burke and Jennifer Schnabel; individual chapters, the contributors
abstract.ce:para: The iconic character of Jessica Fletcher in Murder, She Wrote is particularly noteworthy in the study of television history because she is an older female protagonist and a skilled investigator, a change from the more traditional male detective archetype viewers were accustomed to seeing on their screens. However, Jessica’s identity as a popular mystery writer is equally important to understanding the gender stereotypes the show both embodies and subverts throughout the 12-season series. This paper analyzes the pilot episode, “The Murder of Sherlock Holmes,” (1984) and the fairy tale themed episode “Mirror, Mirror on the Wall” (1989) through the lens of feminist literary criticism, specifically Sandra M. Gilbert and Susan Gubar’s essay, “The Queen’s Looking Glass: Female Creativity, Male Images of Women, and the Metaphor of Literary Paternity” (1979). It also offers supporting examples from the series to examine how Murder, She Wrote discusses paternalistic treatment of women mystery writers.

abstract.publishercopyright: © 2025 selection and editorial matter, Eva Burke and Jennifer Schnabel; individual chapters, the contributors
abstract.ce:para: In recent projects, the author analysed differences among episodes written by men and those written by women, finding that women writers created relationships between female characters that were distinctly more compatible than those created by men writers. Even though those previous studies focused on shows from the 1960s and 1970s, the same analysis is worthy of study in the 12 seasons of Murder, She Wrote. Out of the 264 episodes, 25 are written or co-written by women television writers (17 written and 8 co-written). Thus, just 9.5% of Murder, She Wrote episodes were written by women; yet, when fandom websites rank episodes by popularity, women-written episodes dominate proportionally. For example, when Screenrant.com ranks the 10 best Cabot Cove episodes, 50% were written by women, and when IMDB.com lists the top 10 most popular episodes, 30% were written by women. More importantly, the episodes are unique in their treatment of women’s issues, including feminism, sexual desire, housework, and aging. This chapter seeks to reveal these findings and establish meaningful trends by comparing and analysing all 25 women-written episodes of Murder, She Wrote.

citation-title.titletext: Murder, She Wrote; Bridging the Gap between the Golden Age and Cozy Mysteries

affiliation.ce:source-text: Phyllis M. Betz is a professor emerita in English at La Salle University in Philadelphia, PA. Since retiring, she has focused her critical work on mystery fiction, with a specialty in the cozy. Her edited collection, Reading the Cozy Mystery: Critical Essays on an Underappreciated Subgenre (McFarland), was awarded the 2021 International Crime Fiction Association Book Prize.

Phyllis M. Betz is a professor emerita in English at La Salle University in Philadelphia, PA. Since retiring, she has focused her critical work on mystery fiction, with a specialty in the cozy. Her edited collection, Reading the Cozy Mystery: Critical Essays on an Underappreciated Subgenre (McFarland), was awarded the 2021 International Crime Fiction Association Book Prize.

abstract.publishercopyright: © 2025 selection and editorial matter, Eva Burke and Jennifer Schnabel individual chapters, the contributors
abstract.ce:para: Murder She Wrote has become the short-hand illustration of the cozy mystery, due to how the series took the conventions of the classic detective novel and adapted them to become the foundation for the cozy mystery novel. The television series appeared during the time period when the classical mystery had ceded its dominant position to other mystery sub-genres, like the police procedural and hard-boiled novel. This chapter analyzes how, by reframing the basic attributes of the protagonist, setting, and investigation, Jessica Fletcher helped establish the appeal of the cozy.

citation-title.titletext: Misogyny She Wrote: How Murder, She Wrote Typifies the Backlash against Feminism

affiliation.ce:source-text: Mary P. Freier is Professor Emeritus at Northen Michigan University. She has presented and published on mystery fiction since 1980s, when she watched Murder, She Wrote regularly.

abstract.publishercopyright: © 2025 selection and editorial matter, Eva Burke and Jennifer Schnabel; individual chapters, the contributors
abstract.ce:para: The character of Jessica Fletcher in the popular series Murder, She Wrote was hailed from the start as a positive depiction of an older woman in television. However, examining the depiction of other women in the series and Jessica’s response to them shows us that the series is a perfect example of the backlash against feminism, as described by Susan Faludi in Backlash: The Undeclared War Against American Women (1991). Women characters, whether television producers or prisoners who express feminist views are treated negative, angry, and hysterical. The other women of Cabot Cove, Maine, whom viewers don’t meet until the series is well underway, are depicted as stereotypical women from several decades previously. Although she is offended by the sexist (and ageist) attitudes of the police detectives she encounters, she does not express explicitly feminist views in support of other women. Indeed, Jessica distances herself from feminism, explaining often that she prefers to be addressed as “Mrs.” rather than “Ms.” While she is supportive of individual women, she is not going to take on the patriarchy. While Jessica Fletcher is a beloved television icon, the series is still very much a product of its times.

citation-title.titletext: "This Woman Has a Brilliant Criminal Mind": Information Behavior of a Widow Woman from Maine

affiliation.ce:source-text: Michelle M. Kazmer, PhD, is Dean of the College of Communication and Information, and Professor of Information, at Florida State University. She has been conducting research in the area of crime fiction since 2014, using information science theories to analyse the works of Golden Age writers such as Agatha Christie and Rex Stout.

Michelle M. Kazmer, PhD, is Dean of the College of Communication and Information, and Professor of Information, at Florida State University. She has been conducting research in the area of crime fiction since 2014, using information science theories to analyse the works of Golden Age writers such as Agatha Christie and Rex Stout.

abstract.publishercopyright: © 2025 selection and editorial matter, Eva Burke and Jennifer Schnabel; individual chapters, the contributors
abstract.ce:para: This analysis of Jessica Fletcher takes a perspective drawn from information behavior studies – because detection is surely an information behavior – to reveal an underexplored aspect of Fletcher’s approach to mystery solving. Using information worlds theory, the author analyzes Jessica Fletcher’s information behavior to demonstrate that she is physically vigorous in going after solutions to mysteries, and uses forensically-tangible clues, keen sensory observation, and rigorous logic techniques to root out evil. Fletcher uses complex and sophisticated tools and tactics to manipulate information value and shape her relationships with those around her to facilitate information exchange and eventually allow her to elucidate the solution to a mystery.

affiliation.ce:source-text: Sharon Dempsey is the author of three crime novels, Little Bird (Bloodhound, 2017), Who Took Eden Mulligan? (Harper Collins Avon, 2021) and The Midnight Killing (Harper Collins Avon, 2022) and two novellas. She graduated with a creative writing doctorate from Queen’s University in 2023. Sharon has also published three non-fiction books and has many short stories published in anthologies, literary journals, magazines and broadcast on radio. Sharon been named as one of the Seamus Heaney Centre’s inaugural Ciaran Carson Writing and the City Fellows for 2024–2025. Her new novel, After the Party, will be published later this year.

abstract.ce:para: This critical essay explores how Murder, She Wrote, and the character of Jessica Fletcher, is subversively feminist and an important influencer in showcasing the underrepresented older female character as sleuth. It will discuss Jessica’s spinsterhood and how this status allows her to transcend, to some extent, heteronormative expectations. It also examines Anna Katherine Green’s Amelia Butterworth as a similarly desexualised female sleuth.

citation-title.titletext: "...Something Sultry and Seductive about This Place": New Orleans in the Murder, She Wrote Imagination

affiliation.ce:source-text: Jill E. Anderson is the author of Homemaking for the Apocalypse: Domesticating Horror in the Atomic Age and co-editor of the open-access journal Shirley Jackson Studies. She is studying to become an archivist but for now is an associate professor of English at an historically Black college/university (HBCU).

Jill E. Anderson is the author of Homemaking for the Apocalypse: Domesticating Horror in the Atomic Age and co-editor of the open-access journal Shirley Jackson Studies. She is studying to become an archivist but for now is an associate professor of English at an historically Black college/university (HBCU).

abstract.ce:para: As a stand-in for an extraordinary, worldly type of Southernness, New Orleans occupies a unique place in the American imagination. While some would argue that New Orleans is not stereotypically Southern given its distinct history (and that debate could occupy an essay of its own), New Orleans represents a point on the map of the United States that offers a rich cultural shorthand for the Southern charm of a city situated at an American crossroads. Showing up in four episodes of Murder, She Wrote, New Orleans is portrayed as a worldly city with rough edges and a complicated relationship to racial politics, and that portrayal is true for MSW. Specifically, Jessica’s encounters with and inside the U.S. South serve as the vehicles through which images of problematic yet ultimately cozy Southernness are transmitted. This chapter draws on literary regionalism’s definition of place to decipher the ways Jessica’s engagement with the South and its people comes to construct a televisual shorthand for the South. While Jessica witnesses various serious political and social issues within the region, the show ultimately retreats from fully engaging with more challenging and egregious systemic issues—namely, racism, sexism, and class distinctions—she functions as the mediator, an educated Yankee interloper of literary local color ilk, comfortably engaging with Southerners from all backgrounds and experiences.

citation-title.titletext: 'Norman Rockwell-land' or 'Death Capital of Maine'?: Race, Social Status, and Parochialism as Factors in the Perceived 'Coziness' of Crime in Reagan-Era Cabot Cove

affiliation.ce:source-text: Allysha Powanda Winburn is a Diplomate of the American Board of Forensic Anthropology, a consulting forensic anthropologist for medicolegal agencies throughout the southeastern US, and an Associate Professor at the University of West Florida, where she researches the skeletal and dental embodiment of lived experiences of social marginalisation.
Mark Winburn is a contractor and woodworker who spent two decades as a cultural resource management archaeologist throughout the continental US and Hawaii.

Cate Bird is a forensic specialist who received her PhD in Anthropology from Michigan State University in 2013. Her work focuses on issues of missing and unidentified persons in US and international contexts.

abstract.ce:para: Forensic anthropologists are specialists in human skeletal analysis and archaeological excavation who apply their expertise to medicolegal death investigation—enabling comprehensive crime-scene recoveries, identifications of unknown decedents, and reconstructions of the circumstances surrounding suspicious deaths. Forensic anthropologists are also social scientists, trained to observe and interact with the world through a holistic and humanistic lens. As such, they are well-poised to comment both on the technical aspects of death investigation and the broader sociocultural and systemic contexts for those deaths. In this critical essay, the authors apply this technical and theoretical toolkit to the fictional context of death investigation in Cabot Cove, ME, as depicted in the 1984-1996 U.S. television series Murder, She Wrote. They leverage their collective decades of medicolegal, mass-disaster, and human-rights casework to reflect on: 1. demographics of homicide victims in Cabot Cove (i.e., estimated gender, race, socioeconomic status) compared with CDC data for the U.S. during the years 1984-1996; and 2. crime-scene recovery protocols employed by Cabot Cove Sheriff’s Office personnel compared with protocols utilized by contemporary U.S. medicolegal agencies, in order to highlight disconnects that may inform an analysis of why violent crime in this fictional New England town engenders a sense of ‘coziness’ among viewers.

citation-title.titletext: From Murder, She Wrote to La Signora in Giallo Jessica Fletcher as a Pop Culture Icon in Italy

affiliation.ce:source-text: Lucia Casiraghi (Harvard University) holds a PhD in Italian Studies with a minor in Information Science from Indiana University Bloomington. Her dissertation explored the translanguaging practices of Italian youth on social media, focusing on the interaction between global English and Italian dialetti. She is an affiliate of the Center for Computer-Mediated Communication and a member of the Mediated Public Engagement with Technology and Science research team at Indiana University.

Nicolò Salmaso recently earned his PhD in Italian Studies with a minor in American Literature from Indiana University – Bloomington. His dissertation project explored how the stardom of Italian show-woman and transnational icon Raffaella Carrà encouraged unprecedented and compelling embodiments of femininity as well as acceptance by more traditional audiences, still heavily influenced by the Roman Catholic Church. His research looks at the interplay between gender and popular culture in the broadest sense (visual arts, literature, social media, etc.).

abstract.ce:para: This chapter investigates the lasting cultural significance of Murder, She Wrote among Italian viewers belonging to different generations. The authors analyze the adaptation and dubbing processes of La Signora in Giallo, revealing how certain cultural elements and linguistic nuances were reshaped in order to resonate more with the local audience. Additionally, they examine the growth of paratextual elements in Italian surrounding the show, particularly. Jessica Fletcher’s presence on social media and in internet memes. These representations of the character highlight the blending of American and Italian cultural traits, with themes of nostalgia playing a significant role in audience engagement. By bridging television and internet platforms, the Italian version of the series ultimately captures the interplay of global and local identities, solidifying its status within Italian pop culture.

citation-title.titletext: 'Now, Am I Imagining Things, or Isn't that a Little Fairy Person There in among the Flowers?': Constructions of 'Ireland' in Murder, She Wrote

affiliation.ce:source-text: Eva Burke completed her PhD, funded by the Irish Research Council, at the school of English at Trinity College Dublin under the supervision of Dr. Clare Clarke. Her research looks at domestic noir fiction, specifically the work of Gillian Flynn. Eva has published work in the Journal of International Women’s Studies, Feminist Spaces and Trinity Postgraduate Review and the 2018 edited collection From the Domestic to the Dominant: The New Face of Crime Fiction, published by Palgrave Macmillan. She also co-edited a special ‘domestic noir’ issue of Clues: A Journal of Detection.

Eva Burke completed her PhD, funded by the Irish Research Council, at the school of English at Trinity College Dublin under the supervision of Dr. Clare Clarke. Her research looks at domestic noir fiction, specifically the work of Gillian Flynn. Eva has published work in the Journal of International Women’s Studies, Feminist Spaces and Trinity Postgraduate Review and the 2018 edited collection From the Domestic to the Dominant: The New Face of Crime Fiction, published by Palgrave Macmillan. She also co-edited a special ‘domestic noir’ issue of Clues: A Journal of Detection.

abstract.ce:para: One of the most remarkable things about Murder, She Wrote’s cultural longevity has been the sheer breadth of influence it has had outside of Jessica’s native United States. This chapter discusses the series’ popularity in Ireland, particularly interesting in light of its depiction of the country (then in the early-mid 1990s) as a quaint, old-fashioned rural idyll peopled with superstitious villagers and imbued with a certain mysticism. Jessica’s inhabitation of this version of Ireland raises some interesting contradictions and questions, particularly with regard to her status as an independent, child-free older woman. The focus of this chapter is on Murder, She Wrote’s depiction of crime-solving within a fictionalised version of Ireland and the extent to which the show’s appeal within Ireland can tell us something about perceptions of Ireland from within and without.

citation-title.titletext: "Agatha Christie's Ghost May Strike You Dead!": Murder, She Wrote and an Agatha Christie Sense of Murder

affiliation.ce:source-text: Mark Aldridge is Associate Professor of Screen Histories at Southampton Solent University, UK. His specialism includes British television drama and the works of Agatha Christie. His books include T Is for Television: The Small Screen Adventures of Russell T Davies (with Andy Murray, Reynolds and Hearn, 2009), Agatha Christie on Screen (Palgrave Macmillan, 2016), Agatha Christie’s Poirot: The Greatest Detective in the World (HarperCollins, 2020) and Agatha Christie’s Marple: Expert on Wickedness (HarperCollins, 2024).

Mark Aldridge is Associate Professor of Screen Histories at Southampton Solent University, UK. His specialism includes British television drama and the works of Agatha Christie. His books include T Is for Television: The Small Screen Adventures of Russell T Davies (with Andy Murray, Reynolds and Hearn, 2009), Agatha Christie on Screen (Palgrave Macmillan, 2016), Agatha Christie’s Poirot: The Greatest Detective in the World (HarperCollins, 2020) and Agatha Christie’s Marple: Expert on Wickedness (HarperCollins, 2024).

abstract.ce:para: There is no doubt that the character of Jessica Fletcher owes a debt to Agatha Christie’s Miss Marple, who appeared in a dozen novels between 1930 and 1976. However, this chapter argues that Christie’s influence on Murder, She Wrote extended beyond this, particularly in the series’ early years. Christie’s mysteries offered universal themes, characters and narrative techniques that Murder, She Wrote also made use of, even though the series told its stories on American network television several years after Christie’s death. The links between Christie’s writings and Murder, She Wrote are discussed through comparative examples and a consideration of how different cultures and audiences meant that key elements of Christie’s storytelling techniques were both appropriated and altered in the series.

citation-title.titletext: Death in Plastic: A Ludonarrative Analysis of Murder, She Wroteg The Game and Murder on Madison Avenue

affiliation.ce:source-text: Marco Arnaudo is a Professor of Italian at Indiana University, where he teaches classes about literature, comics, games, and military history. His books include Storytelling in the Modern Board Game (2018) and A Tabletop Revolution (2024). He is the designer of the story-driven game Four against the Great Old Ones (2020). He has a video blog about games on YouTube (MarcoOmnigamer) with 25, 000+ subscribers.

Marco Arnaudo is a Professor of Italian at Indiana University, where he teaches classes about literature, comics, games, and military history. His books include Storytelling in the Modern Board Game (2018) and A Tabletop Revolution (2024). He is the designer of the story-driven game Four against the Great Old Ones (2020). He has a video blog about games on YouTube (MarcoOmnigamer) with 25, 000+ subscribers.

abstract.ce:para: This chapter examines the convergence of game discourses and narrative representation in relation to the TV show Murder, She Wrote. This ludonarrative analysis discusses how fiction can influence games (as in the tabletop game Murder, She Wrote) and how games can be represented in fiction (as in the episode 8.22 of the show, where Jessica acts as a game designer). After discussing the concept of paratextual games and sketching the context for this kind of product in the 1980s, the chapter looks at the real-life board game Murder, She Wrote as a ludically effective design and yet also as a dissonant representation of the core concepts of the show.

citation-title.titletext: Re-watching Murder, She Wrote: An Auto-Ethnographic Exploration of Queer Fandom and Race

affiliation.ce:source-text: Nina Trivedi is a Senior Lecturer in Design: Race and Intercultural Studies at Central St Martins, University of the Arts, London. Nina completed a PhD at the Royal College of Art in Critical and Historical studies.

Nina Trivedi is a Senior Lecturer in Design: Race and Intercultural Studies at Central St Martins, University of the Arts, London. Nina completed a PhD at the Royal College of Art in Critical and Historical studies.

abstract.ce:para: The chapter applies an autoethnographic approach to examine Murder, She Wrote while critically interrogating issues of race and queerness. It particularly focuses on the visibility and invisibility of whiteness in American media, exploring how queer fandoms connect with the show and how fans of color navigate its predominantly white spaces. By engaging with José Esteban Muñoz’s theory of “disidentification,” the chapter addresses how marginalized viewers reinterpret mainstream media to align with their experiences. This chapter critiques the show’s evolving portrayal of race by drawing on media analysis and contrasting episodes, while also reflecting on fan events and how they engage with issues of representation. Incorporating insights from bell hooks and Dylan Robinson, the author questions whether the show’s representation genuinely advances racial inclusion or perpetuates harmful stereotypes, offering broader perspectives on the potential for fandom to foster inclusivity and critical engagement.
